claim: The largest animal living in Loch Ness is the Loch Ness Monster.

supporting.text: There is no scientific evidence confirming the existence of the Loch Ness Monster.

attacks.text: There is no scientific evidence confirming the existence of the Loch Ness Monster.
Eyewitness accounts and anecdotal evidence suggest the existence of the Loch Ness Monster.
Eyewitness accounts are unreliable and often influenced by psychological factors like pareidolia or hoaxes.
Sonar readings and underwater photographs have shown unexplained large objects in Loch Ness.
Sonar readings can be misinterpreted, and underwater photographs are often inconclusive or debunked as natural phenomena.

supporting.text: The largest known animal in Loch Ness is the European eel, based on documented species.

attacks.text: The largest known animal in Loch Ness is the European eel, based on documented species.
There is no conclusive evidence that the European eel is the largest animal in Loch Ness, as the ecosystem may harbor undocumented species.
Scientific surveys and sonar scans of Loch Ness have not detected any species larger than the European eel, supporting its status as the largest documented animal.
Eyewitness accounts and photographic evidence suggest the existence of a larger creature, possibly the Loch Ness Monster.
Eyewitness accounts are often unreliable and can be attributed to misidentifications of known animals or natural phenomena.

supporting.text: Sonar and underwater surveys of Loch Ness have not detected any large unidentified creatures.

attacks.text: Sonar and underwater surveys of Loch Ness have not detected any large unidentified creatures.
Sonar and underwater surveys have limitations in detecting creatures that may avoid detection or inhabit areas not thoroughly scanned.
Modern sonar technology is highly advanced and capable of detecting large objects even in deep or murky waters.
Historical eyewitness accounts and photographs suggest the existence of a large unidentified creature in Loch Ness.
Eyewitness accounts are often unreliable and can be influenced by hoaxes or misidentifications of known animals.

supporting.text: The Loch Ness Monster is a myth originating from folklore and unverified sightings.

attacks.text: The Loch Ness Monster is a myth originating from folklore and unverified sightings.
There have been multiple sonar readings and photographs that suggest the presence of a large, unidentified creature in Loch Ness.
Many of the sonar readings and photographs attributed to the Loch Ness Monster have been debunked as hoaxes or misidentifications of known animals or objects.
Some sonar readings remain unexplained by conventional explanations, leaving room for the possibility of an unknown large creature.
Folklore and myths often have roots in real phenomena, suggesting that the Loch Ness Monster legend could be based on actual encounters with a large animal.
Without concrete evidence such as DNA samples or a captured specimen, the Loch Ness Monster remains in the realm of myth rather than verified fact.

supporting.text: Marine biology studies of Loch Ness confirm no large unknown species inhabit the lake.

attacks.text: Marine biology studies of Loch Ness confirm no large unknown species inhabit the lake.
Marine biology studies may have limited detection capabilities for elusive or deep-dwelling creatures.
Modern sonar and environmental DNA sampling techniques are highly effective at detecting large aquatic species.
Historical eyewitness accounts and photographs provide evidence of an unidentified large creature in Loch Ness.
Eyewitness accounts are often unreliable and can be influenced by hoaxes or misidentifications of known animals.
